I'll agree with @aviemzur that the "file where each line is a JSON record" would be easily supported by TextIO.Read + JsonParse  / JsonFormat + TextIO.Write. I think that is a very common format for storing JSON.

I also acknowledge @eljefe6a's point that this would not be a good fit were there newlines inside the JSON records, as is also very common. That would require more thought / "JsonIO". I would probably go ahead and ship this and think about JsonIO separately. (It would be good to have a few motivating examples, too!, to inform the design of JsonIO.)
Thank you. jenkins pre-commit test is green, I will merge this.

Hi guys,
I'm a bit surprised to see this PR without a comment in the data format extension discussion.
As reminder, we started a discussion to provide an extension to deal with different data format: JSON, XML, ... and provide `PTransforms` to convert from one format to another (format converters).

I started a PoC about this here:

https://github.com/jbonofre/beam/tree/DATAFORMAT

and the discussion on the dev mailing list.

IMHO, all about data format converters should be in a data format module.

R: @amitsela  @rangadi 

Based on your experience and involvement in the relevant recent discussions, would one of you two like to take a pass? Given that this code has been heavily used in Scio, my expectation is that it is already very high quality.

I know there are other discussions going on related to the future of these IOs, but I think it's worth accepting these well-vetted improvements (pending your reviews ;) and then pursuing the "right" long-term structure later.

Hi JB,

I don't think a single "Dataformat" module is necessarily all that useful.
For one, it would likely have lots of dependencies.

To enable many contributors and forward progress, IMO I am leaning towards
taking small improvements in PR without worrying too hard about long-term
structure -- especially as extensions.

For Dataformat -- I guess I had forgotten about it, sorry. I couldn't find
an active JIRA, or an active PR, for DATA_FORMAT. Your POC hasn't been
touched in 3 months.

Dan

On Thu, Feb 16, 2017 at 11:18 PM, Jean-Baptiste Onofré <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I'm a bit surprised to see this PR without a comment in the data format
> extension discussion.

So, you propose to create one module per data format.

My branch was waiting for more discussion/traction on the mailing list.

I'm OK with the proposal: one module per format.

I will update the Jira (I created a Jira about the data format extension), and I will create the PR for XML data format (with JAXB).

I think JB's module is a good idea.

I agree with Dan that if a user just wants JSON for example, they don't want to be bombarded with a lot of other dependencies they don't use.

There is a solution though, JB's module can be a supermodule of individual formats modules, and there can also be a formats-all module which has dependencies on all of them, for convenience (If a user doesn't care about the unnecessary dependencies), or a user can just add a dependency on a specific module.

Then, the JSON module can just be moved under this supermodule when it is introduced in the future.

I agree with Dan and Aviem comments about dependencies and the way of moving format.
The number of data format is not so large, so that's why I thought about a "gather" data format module first (and it's what we discussed on the mailing list).
However, to speed up contribution, let's start with one module per format.

R: @tgroh 

Thomas, can you take a look at this? Very similar to the sharding stuff you did for TextIO.Write, I think.

Sorry for the delay! I missed the real comment between the bot noise on the JIRA. I answer there, but the basic thing is that namespaces are generalized beyond what user timers need. You only need `WindowNamespace`.

Last time I worked on this, we actually decided to be lax about it because we don't have a short-term story for getting all runners to agree. I don't know that there's any design or consensus. Bytecode generation also changed exactly what was user code or not.

My favored style is a `PipelineExecutionException` with a cause that indicates whether the user actually threw the exception or the runner threw the exception, with a cause that is details. But that might not actually be friendly when dumped. Fn API will make this distinction quite stark so that seems the most expedient way towards a design. In a sense, the thing that has already bitten us many times is the distinction between "user exception" and "SDK harness exception" - the runner exceptions are already fairly well separated I think.

For this case, I'm not sure where the assertion failure is coming from (which is why it isn't a `RuntimeException`); I think the stack trace truncation might be hiding the details. I'd love to just follow the pattern we have already so we can save design work for later.

Changing the test to some other common superclass of exceptions would definitely work, but this feels solvable by more investigation.

There's [a comment](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/testing/TestPipeline.java#L91) in `TestPipeline` that we must do so for `PAssert` failures. I don't believe there's been any work put into having consistent exceptions thrown from a non-assertion-based failure; part of that is due to differing retry behavior, flaky dependencies, etc (e.g. what if work fails in four different ways in Dataflow? which one "counts" as the one that failed the Pipeline?)

We also don't really have a strong contract on the behavior of `getState()` or `waitToFinish()`, at least at the `Pipeline` level - they only say ["Returning the Final State"](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/PipelineResult.java#L62).

r: @charlesccychen 
I am adding the feature to make users able to query metrics when they run jobs on the dataflow runner. I have a couple questions regarding this:

* Currently, every call to `DataflowMetrics.query()` requires an API call to the dataflow service. Should we try to be smart and cache the API call if calls to `DataflowMetrics.query()` are within a minute or so of each other/if the job is completed?

Also, there's no support for distributions yet, so we are intentionally excluding them.
If the integration tests pass, LGTM.

@jiajiayb: this may be due to a mismatch between the Cloud ML SDK and the Beam / Dataflow SDK version.  See the instructions here for more details (select the "Local: Mac / Linux" tab of "Setting up your environment"): https://cloud.google.com/ml/docs/how-tos/getting-set-up

You may want to go through the entirety of the instructions, but this command may fix your particular issue:

```
pip install --upgrade --force-reinstall \
    https://storage.googleapis.com/cloud-ml/sdk/cloudml.latest.tar.gz
```
